reviewText:
***UPDATE MARCH 2014*************
I added another one to my personal arsenal - The newest addition gets bumped down a star - Still a good C Stand but there are some noticeable differences in quality (nothing major, but still enough to warrant an update) - The newest one is a tad heavier (by 3.5 lbs) which isn't a big deal to me, and may or may not matter to you either, but worth a mention none the less;
The gobo head does not tighten as securely around the extension arm as the first stand. It holds a firm grip but the gap is evident. I compared it with the first gobo and swapped arms, measured and it's obvious that the new gobo was machined a little off calibration wise. This stand didn't come 'assembled' either - also not a big deal but the first stand was prime eligible and arrived assembled in 2 days with free shipping - Which brings me to the last mediocre 'con' - No prime shipping, UPS Ground, pricey and SLOW - Size warrants a bulky box, and bulky box will probably arrive bruised and crushed since the C Stand only takes up 1/4 of the box, making the parcel vulnerable to being crushed from top (which isn't going to damage the stand but still an issue as far as shipping woes)
Still a good stand, just not as friendly on the budget after $30 shipping, lag time, no prime eligibility, etc, I probably should of just spent a few extra bucks and got a Kupo, Matthews, etc - 4 out of 5 stars - Shop around or spend the extra coin and get a name brand with prime.

Great high quality C Stand here! One of the many downsides of photography and film is that it is def not a poor man's hobby as most people quickly learn as they expand their equipment. This is more of a myth these days as lighting kits and equipment become cheaper in price and more accessible to the amateur. The common problem is the cheaper the price, the cheaper the quality.

Not the case here.

This C Stand is just as good as my Matthews, and 1/2 the price. The rubber grip is an added bonus too. Solidly built, it is holding up just fine. I was a bit leery of buying this at first, as I have had the usual woes with cheap plastic stands, but this is by no means a cheaply built product. Does the job great, folds easy for storage and it compliments my name brand in both durability and quality.

My only advice would be to shop around. The price fluctuates on these, and while I feel I got a great price, if I can save even more $$ I will. I plan on adding a few more to my arsenal, as they are invaluable on any shoot.

reviewText:
This is a very good radar detector with some nice features you just won't find many, if any, other places.

Range: The range on this unit can be very good, especially on Ka Band. It will meet or exceed the range of many high end detectors and have excellent off-axis sensitivity to pick up radar signals that may not be directly in front of you. One note, K band range has tested good but not excellent. It has been sufficient in my area but is not on the same level as the Ka range. If K is not a big concern in your area, not issues. If K is your primary threat, you may want to consider its bigger brother the SE or another unit all together. For me it is a non issue and leads to less false alerts.

Filtering: Multiple options for filtering. Speed based muting keeps everything under a certain speed limit very quiet. One alert and then it mutes. Additional speed based city and auto city modes will lower sensitivity to X, K, and Ka bands based on your preference at a pre set speed (such as your typically speed limit in your area). Another level under that mutes everything completely. Good for parking lots and such (think 15 mph and lower). In addition it has two levels of TSR filtering. Most radar detectors only have one. Low adds a short delay to K band alerts to be sure that it is not a traffic filter or blind spot monitor system found on some newer cars. High makes the delay longer to accomplish the same thing. Use whichever works for you. The lower the better as the shorter delay allows the detector to respond more quickly.

GPS: This detector also has GPS lockout features built in. I don't personally use them as the GPS speed sensitive alerts referenced above are sufficient for me and I don't have to worry about accidentally locking out a real threat. Radenso is working on a firmware update to change the way lockouts are handled. In addition to lockouts, this detector offers Speed Camera, Redlight Camera, and Speed Trap Camera GPS alerts and the database is free (included with cost of detector). This is very important if these can be found in your area.

Additional PROS: The size. This this is tiny. Should be able to find a place for this thing in any vehicle. Other detectors that don't have GPS are much larger. The mount works very well. They are constantly improving this unit through downloadable firmware updates as well as the Speedcam, Redlightcam, and Speed Trap Database. They say they are enthusiast driven and are working hard on continuous improvement. That is a plus.

CONS: If I had to point out a few things that could be better. I sometimes have trouble viewing the screen wearing Polarized Sunglasses. This can be mitigated some by changing the angle or moving the location on the windshield. The power connector is a type typically seen on cheaper detectors, could have used a style similar to Escort, Beltronics, and Uniden. The case does not feel as substantial as the price tag might indicate. Not necessarily a huge deal as long as you didn't buy it to hold or stare at and admire.

reviewText:
I had gotten this for primarily gym usage.  Here's my thoughts after a few hours of use:

Pros:

1) GREAT sound...really brings out the clarity and deep bass in my MP3's. I usually use my HTC EVO 4G for music...I think I'll be switching over to the Sony now, as it sounds that good.

2) It IS actually Rhapsody compatible: I've transferred about 10 playlists with no issues

3) Folder support.  Wish this was standard in all music players for those of us who like
to organize music by actual folders

4) Dedicated toggle switch for headphone/speakers...nice!

5) Fairly decent stereo speakers.

Cons:

1) SLOW transfer rate.  Took an hour to transfer 5GB of DRM-free mp3's (without any file conversion).  I have a reasonably powerful computer: 2.8Ghz Athlon II Dual Core, 4GB RAM, Win 7 (64-bit), fast 500GB SATA hard disk.  Also latest firmware and transfer software.

2) Feels very light, cheap, and "plasticy"...I think I'll be getting a case for this since I plan to use at the gym.  It has NO feeling of sturdiness to it...and NO clip or case of any kind included.

3) Comes with a separate cheap kickstand that can't be attached that you'll probably lose VERY quickly.  Not that you'd really want to watch video on this thing anyway vs. any decent cell phone these days.  My EVO 4G's screen blows it away, naturally.

4) It LOOKS like the external speakers are on the front...but they're not.  They're actually on the back of the unit, and when you set it down on a table the speakers are completely flush with the table so the speakers get severely muffled.  Very strange design choice, in my opinion.

5) No expandable storage...no micro-SD slot.  Although with 16GB of storage I guess I'll be ok.

6) Non-standard input for USB connectivity (Typical for SONY...this is SO annoying...now I'll need to buy a separate extra charger and cable since it only came with one USB cable and no charger)

7) Stops after reaching end of album/folder.  You can choose to repeat an album/folder but it can't proceed to next one after it finishes...kind of stupid when even my Sony MP3 stereo from 2004 can do that.

Overall, I recommend it if you don't need the latest and greatest iPod with a bunch of frills, and ONLY care about sound, battery life, and decent capacity...which is what I was looking for at just over $100 new.

reviewText:
Put simply, this inverter turns your car's cigarette lighter into a three-prong outlet (for electronic device that use 100 W or less). In addition to the outlet it also has a USB outlet.

The usefulness of the inverter are clear: it saves you from needing an adapter for each one of your electronic devices that you want to use in the car -- it's one stop shopping. Anything with a two or three-prong plug can plug into it.

The inverter is small enough that it can easily fit into a glove box (taking up about as much space as a GPS) or into your computer bag.

During use I didn't notice anything unusual about the operation. Despite the fan it runs pretty quietly.

My one complaint is that the chord that goes into the cigarette lighter is so short that the inverter cannot reach the back seat or rear of the car. That means passengers are dependent on the people in the front of the car to plug and unplug devices. I took off one star for that.

Recommended.

reviewText: I have purchased the Amazon Basics 50 mile range and the Mohu Leaf 50 and found them to be identical.  I live in the suburbia that is SoCal with other houses less than 10 feet on either side and 40 feet behind.  I live 39 miles from the broadcast towers in LA.  Those 2 indoor antennae each pulled in 119 channels, but not 2 of the major networks.  This made them useless as I don't really care for 100 of those channels.  I bought this antenna expecting to mount it on the side of my chimney to get up over the neighbor's roofline as that is the direction that [...] said I needed.  I tried it in the attic first, just kind of standing it up against a beam and I picked up 170+ channels and the 2 networks that I was missing!  Now, granted, I may have been able to put one of the indoor antennae up there and achieved similar results, but the ruggedness of this one and the fact that I returned one (the Mohu) and connected the other to another TV made sense.

reviewText:
Packaging - Frustration free so it arrives loosely dangling in a regular thick envelope. The drive just bounces around inside, but this is all solid state so should be ok. The only worry is the mechanical parts such as the USB plug that extends out and the plastic casing it sits in.

Price - good price point of 50cents/GB.

Capacity - Good at 64GB

Speed - I am getting average write speeds of around 7.5MB/s (sometimes spikes to 15MB/s as well!) which is decent. I just did an rsync of my linux files to here and 7.5MB/s is not that bad. I transferred 50GB of data to it in  . Files were a mixture of <100KB to over 100MB. Haven't tested with the video files which are 1.5GB on average yet.
So it is not really the fastest drive. Read speeds are much higher at around 15MB/s avg as expected.
This is also a USB 2.0 drive. With a USB 3.0 drive, speeds should be much faster.

Bundled software - thankfully this is a blank drive with nothing on it.

Other thoughts -
I bought the Transcend 64GB over the Patriot Rage 64GB because that is twice the cost of this, but that does offer double write speed as well. Still I am not too worried about this because it is very good for its price.

Also Due to the way storage is reported (2^10 vs 10^3 i.e. 1024 bytes making up a GB in engineering notation vs 1000 making up a GigaByte in SI notation), the drive formatted reported is 61GB. Rest assured, it is the same as advertised. The drive companies use powers of 10 whereas computers use powers of 2 causing this confusion. To avoid this, everyone should just report it in the standard Engineering notation of Kibi, Mibi, Gibi etc. Technically this is a 61GiB drive.

reviewText:
I'm a little disappointed in this item. It's probably partly my fault because at $13.00 I wouldn't have normally been expecting much, but since it said it was marked down from the regular price of $25.00, I thought maybe it would be OK. I have two problems with it.

1. This has been mentioned before, but in portrait mode, This case doesn't really provide much support. In the first position, with the Fire standing nearly upright, it almost always collapses and just falls backward. At the middle position, it seems to work OK as long as you're not doing much with the touch screen. If all you're doing is reading and touching it lightly to flip pages, it might be alright, but when pressing in a way that I consider normal, like tapping on the screen to open an app, or swiping with your finger is likely to make it collapse. I haven't tried the third setting with the fire positioned at about 25 to 30 degrees might work OK, but I'm not likely to use it in that position very often.

It seems to work a little better in the horizontal position because the side edge is making more contact with the case than in the vertical position.

The most obvious problem I see is that the raised strips in the cover that are trying to support the device and the edge of the case the Fire fits in that catches the raised edges just don't have enough contact with each other to keep the device secure. Maybe if the raised portion was higher, or there was some kind of small lip for the edge of the device case to catch it would work better, but as it is, there isn't much there to keep it from slipping off and collapsing when you tap, or swipe your finger on the touch screen.
I think I can make this work okay by using a little velcro on the raised strips and the edge of the Fire's case, so I'll probably keep it and play with making it work.

2. The description I read said that this is a leather case. I may be wrong, but I've been using leather accessories for a long time and if this is leather, it's not a leather from any animal I'm familiar with. It smells like something that is definitely man made and is actually fairly thin. I know, at $13.00 I'm being a little nit picky, but if the description says leather I expect it to smell like leather and not plastic.

On the plus side, it does have an elastic strap you can pull over the cover that keeps it closed securely.

I purchased this because there is only one other case I've seen that allows you to use the Fire in either the vertical, or horizontal position and I use both my phone and the Fire in each position a fairly equal amount of time, depending on what I'm using it for at the time.

Perhaps we'll have a better choice in cases once the Fire has been out for a while. As many Fire's as Amazon is selling, I would expect to see a lot more cases coming out and I'd recommend waiting for something that's designed and made a little better with better material. You might also look at cases for the 7" Samsung Galaxy Tab, or the Blackberry Rim since they're the same size.

I'm giving this 3 stars, mainly because I do like the snap that allows me to swivel the Fire from horizontal to vertical, but the quality isn't that great and I'm going to have to make some modifications to make it work without collapsing when using the touch screen.

reviewText:
As always for a review, I give the product time. In this case the EX51LP needed time for me to get adjusted to the "hot" sound.

Here "hot" means the bass and treble notes sound emphacised compared to other phones, especially the Ipod's. Not bad mind you, just more in your face type of sound. I use them with the Shuffle, which you may know has the best bass response of all the Ipods (ref PCMag tests also check their new issue where they rate the 71's higher than Shure E3c)so the bass was really,Really right there. It may be a bit too bright on the low and high end, but it also eliminates the need for equalization for me. Other phones will sound dull after this, not necessarily more accurate, but definitively more dull. Ipod lounge is another good source for many "bud" and other phones comparisons as well. The specs for 51's and 71's are identical, as is the sound, the mounts on the 81's are a bit different but the sound is similar, people hate the two piece cord on the 71's. The wire lengths on the 51's are preferred by a vast majority, left ear is about 4", right 12", the joint cord about 4ft. The cord is tangle prone, and the little "wrap" case is useless, use an Altoids can instead. All of the 3 sizes of the ear pads fit in my ear OK, the inserts are THAT soft. The buds are small enough that you can fall asleep on the side of your head, and they will not hurt. They are not very efficient at 100db, the Ipod players are very loud at 1/2 full, but for instance my Panasonic MP3 CD player had to be turned almost all the way up. Informed opinion is that that the higher level Etymotics and Shure buds are more accurate although not as "hot" or "impressive" sounding. But for sheer performance under 100$ you will be hard pressed to do better.

reviewText: I, like the precious buyer, bought these headphones directly from Velodyne for a ridiculously cheap price. As far as my review of the actual headphones goes, for $200 you'll be disappointed because you can instead get something superior like the vmoda m80s. However I think for $100 or less these headphones are fantastic. They're light and made of plastic but the quality is top notch. Less creaking than beats solos. The bass is fantastic as are the highs. Overall sound is better than the beats solos. I would say they are close in sound to the beats mixr. The vmoda m80s are better build and sound but the sound isn't immensely better. As long as you get these for $100 or less you're getting a good deal on great headphones

reviewText:
As everyone else who had reviewed this product noted, it has great sound and looks super cool.  I already love it in comparison to the other small speaker systems that I've take on trips in the past.  Unfortunately, I have to give it 4 stars because I know for a fact that it will break on me after a while.

The issue is the plastic tab that you use to pull the speaker cable out from the body with... it's super flimsy and the tab already shows stress marks after my first time opening it.  It's basically a piece of plastic as thin as paper and as small as match head that you have to grasp with your finger nails and pull on any time you open it, and it's part of the normal molding so don't think that it's going to be especially durable plastic.  The same two plastic tabs get stuck on the carrying case liner when you put it in and out of it's protective case.  I guess that I'm going to try and super glue some better handles on myself to preemptively fix the issue.

Still, it's a pretty clever design and I think that it's going to work out well.

reviewText: Overall, an excellent pair of IEMs. This is the second most expensive set of headphones I've ever owned so I don't have a lot to compare them to. But I can say that they are lightyears ahead of anything you can find for less than $50.  The treble is clear and precise without sounding harsh. The bass is present, not thumpy. I absolutely hate bass-boosted headphones that sacrifice sound quality and balance for harder thumps. These offer a balanced sound, meaning the bass is there without taking away from the rest of the sound spectrum. If you want earth shattering, look elsewhere. The most impressive thing about these IEMs for me is the clarity of the sound. I feel like I'm hearing the music the way the artist intended it to be heard. I've thrown alternative, classic rock, metal, jazz, and some indie/folk at these and they handled all of them well, but I must say that the sound truly shines on softer acoustic type tracks. So if you want to more of the subtle nuances of your music and enjoy exceptionally crisp and clear sound without overpowering bass, get these.

reviewText:
I'm editing my entire review.  I first gave this 1 star because it didn't meet my expectations.  I have purchased 2 other tube shaped cameras.  It turns out I was expecting too much for a small tube shaped camera.  The other cameras I have are the Ion Air Pro Lite, Sena Prism Tube and some other no-name tube cam not worth naming.  This cam by far has the most features.  Ion may have tried to cram too many features into this cam.  Not all the non essential features will work well, but I don't use them all anyway.  The ones I do use seem to work well.  This review will basically be a comparison with the Sena Prism Tube.  .

What the Air Pro 3 HAS, where the Prism Tube does not: Very wide viewing angle. Once accustomed to having this extra wide angle available, it's hard to live with a narrower angle.  You can select different recording resolutions, although I leave mine at 1080 / 30fps all the time. It takes still photos, actually pretty nice ones at 12 megapixels.  The Prism Tube does not take still shots.  It has a built-in mic, but also has a standard mic jack for an external mic.  So, you don't need a proprietary mic.  The Prism Tube has no built-in mic, and requires a proprietary mic.  It has image stabilization. I questioned if the stabilization was actually working for a while, but when comparing with the Prism Tube which does not have stabilization, I can tell it's working.  Video is also not distorted during vibration and movement.  The Prism Tube's image sometimes seems jagged or distorted.  It is water proof, not just water resistant.  You can take it underwater up to 3 meters as long as the rear cover is attached.  Color is pretty accurate in all lighting conditions.  With the Prism tube, bright lighting often can throws off color balance.

What this does NOT have that the Prism Tube does have:  It's at least 30% larger in diameter than the Prism Tube.  I wish they would have made this cam a little smaller instead of trying to pack too many features into it.  I don't need WiFi, social media sharing, etc.  It doesn't have a side mount for your helmet.  I had to make my own.  Underwater videos and images are blurry.  In all fairness, the Prism Tube can't even go underwater.  Sound quality, even with a good external mic is poor.  It doesn't seem to pick up low tones at all.

So, iON, I'm sorry I gave you a bad initial review.  I was wrong.

reviewText:
This flash is fantastic. I took it out of the box and put it to use without reading the manual. If you're familiar with the different modes on other flashes, strobes, and godox triggers such as the XT32-C or N then the menus are pretty self explanatory. The flash that I purchased was for the Sony system. The cameras that I used it with were Sony A7rII and A6300.

I used it on New Year's eve to cover a party. I first tried the TTL mode which works flawlessly. Seems to take a little longer in duration between shots to fire compared to manual mode, but I was very reliable. The recycle time in manual mode is extremely quick and even though the location had extremely high ceilings that was no problem for bounce flash. I also had a few AD600's setup in different locations with backdrops. I switched to the controller mode and it worked flawlessly. I was able to change the power and on my AD600s with ease which made going from room to room extremely stress free. I did not have to update any firmware before using. It works great right out of the box.

I uploaded a few images from New Year's eve night that I captured using the flash in all mentioned modes. The flash is definitely one of the best and versatile on/off camera flashes that I've used for both Sony and Canon cameras. Shipping was faster than expected. I purchased from seller LETWING.

reviewText:
I bought this HDMI switcher to share a port between a Roku 2 XD and a Apple TV 2nd Generation.  It switches seamlessly between the two without an external power supply.  The price was definitely right too.

I have two quibbles with this switch, the bright blue status LED and the external IR receiver.  I don't know why so many manufacturers put the blue status lights on devices for home theater equipment because even a single status light can easily light up a room.  The other problem was the external IR receiver.  The receiver has a short cord, which does not help when you are trying to hide that bright blue status light.  The IR receiver also had a very limited field from which it could pick up a signal.  I had to point directly at the receiver and even then it was flaky. On the upside, I had another IR receiver from a cable box that works fine and allowed me to hide the switcher out of sight.

reviewText:
I'll admit that I'm a tech idiot. I know little about using this stuff but technology is still starting to take over what we do, so reluctantly I use it. This is my first actual GPS unit and the only time I've ever used something like this before was on a roadtrip years ago on my bike. I was lost on unfamiliar country roads and needed a hotel room the GPS feature on my phone was so exact that I could use it in my lane selections. I have not seen that in this unit yet. I have however found out that this thing is like having a tourguide! My wife and I enjoy taking off on the Harley and we often find ourselves in unfamiliar areas where we do not know what our options are for hotels and restaurants, the GPS gave us several options and we were able to find a place to eat that was good and a hotel when needed.
 We are planning another roadtrip and it was very easy to transfer all of the places and routes that we want to ride from the laptop (from Mapquest.com) to the GPS. I think that is a fantastic feature!
 One other con, is that there is quite a bit of glare off the screen on a sunny day, even in the car making it a little frustrating to follow directions.
 I do not look forward to up-dating the unit as it takes hours and slows down everything in the house that used the internet, but it is free, so I tolerate it.
 For my wife (who lives by her smart phone) I am happy that it will answer and make her phone calls with out her having to mess with her phone in the car. I don't use this feature at all.
 For me, I'd be happy if the bluetooth feature would work with my bluetooth stereo on the Harley to call out turn by turn through the bike speakers. (where I might actually hear it)

reviewText:
I bought this for the bass, of course, and the ease of installation. I'll save you some research time and tell you this is one of the few subs that doesn't make you hook up a wire directly from the battery. It's fairly easy to install yourself if you have the motivation. You use the included wiring harness, run the wires from the back to the front (using the car's wiring channels). Then use the FAST 9999 to splice into the wiring harness behind the stereo unit. Piece of cake, 6 color coded wires and you're good to go. No amp necessary either, this has a built in amp, and  the red power wire drives the sub with no problem. The wiring also has RCA connectors if you can't use the high level connectors. Remember though, it's either/or, DO NOT PLUG IN BOTH CONNECTOR TYPES AT THE SAME TIME. I'm not sure why but they make it sound like crossing the streams in Ghostbusters. Just don't try it.

If you're really into sound and music I'm sure you'll want something more expensive, but for the rest of us who need a little bass to fill out the sound in our car, this is more than enough to get the job done. Theres exactly zero bells and whistles here, just an input and a volume knob. No other physical adjustments, but it gets the job done.

Bottom line: this thing is a steal.

summary: If you need more bass than this, you may need to re-think your life.

reviewText:
First of all, I purchased this laptop from the Microsoft store instead of Amazon which comes with no bloat ware and is optimized for Windows (whatever that means).  I was really excited to unbox the laptop and begin using it immediately as this is the lightest and thinnest laptop that I've ever owned and it supposedly gets 10+ hours of battery life.  And as many other reviews have stated, you get a lot of bang for the buck.  At the moment no other laptop gives you a 256gb ssd and 8gb of ram for $699.  The only other feature I wished it has is a backlit keyboard.  I primarily use the laptop for surfing the web, light word processing, and some spreadsheet work and when working on the bed with the lights off, a backlit keyboard is a must.

I didn't run any benchmarks, but all of the work I've done on it so far has gone smoothly.  One thing I did check is the battery life.  I got about 7.5 hours of use off my first charge which I'm happy with since I travel quite a bit and can usually recharge before the battery runs out.  I couldn't say the same for my previous laptop which needed charging after 3 hours so this is a major improvement.

Almost everything about the laptop was perfect....the touchpad however drove me crazy.  For some reason I felt the right click made more noise than it should and just pressing it didn't feel like it clicked properly.  It felt like the touchpad was loose and made a clattering noise every time I pressed it.  I went back to the store and checked out the demo unit and the touchpad on the demo unit was firm and tight fitting.  Then I googled the problem and it seems like others were having the issue too.  I exchanged the laptop for another one and it had the same problem.  I then exchanged it one more time and the 3rd laptop still had the problem!  I was really bummed and was about to return it for a full refund.  I really wanted to keep the computer, but every time I clicked the touchpad it just bothered me.

I searched for a fix and came across a website that showed how to disassemble the laptop.  I was fairly hopeful that if I opened it up, I could easily fix the issue with some electrical tape which would tighten the gap that was making the touchpad behave the way it did.  Well I gently opened the back cover and examined the touchpad area.  I lightly tapped around and noticed that if I pressed against the bottom plate of the touchpad, the touchpad felt much better.  So I added a couple strips of electrical tape and sealed everything back up.  It was enough tape for the bottom cover to firmly press against the touchpad and now it is 99% better.

I would have easily given this laptop 5 stars, but because of this touchpad issue I'm only giving it 4.  If I could not have remedied that problem, I probably would have just returned the laptop and give it a 2 star rating.  I wouldn't recommend this fix for everyone since I probably voided my warranty.  But now that the touchpad doesn't clatter, I feel like its worth it.

reviewText:
Yeah, they're not Bose, but they're also 1/6th of the cost.  However, if you're not a daily  flier, and want to cut out the worst of the noise on an airplane, these headphones certainly do the job.

A marked differential of tone in the left and right channels is a minor annoyance (noted in a previously submitted rating).  The unpadded headband is also somewhat uncomfortable, but is offset by their compact size when you fold them up for storage.

I wear them for 9 to 10 hours on trans-Atlantic flights once a month (and an ocassional domestic flight) and love the convenience of the retractable cord. They are able to cancel out the worst of the engine noise and general whirs and buzzes of any aircraft.  The sound quality and fit comfort are a sight better than the junk that the airlines provide.

If you want the best, buy the best (Bose).  If you want the best value, good performance, and top convenience, buy the JVC from Amazon.

reviewText:
So I got this card today and after owning both the Founder's Edition and this card I can safely say that this card is one of the best out there. First of all it is much quieter than the FE. This is to be expected, but the FE is already the quietest reference card on the market and is very tolerable compared to the old reference cards. The fans turn off unless while gaming and even then it is very quiet. Using my custom fan curve for benchmarking and keeping clocks at stock speeds this card does slightly better (2841) in Unigine Heaven 4.0 than the FE (2771).

With no fan curve it gets to around 75 deg C on load but remains rather quiet, and overall the noise is very similar to my EVGA ACX 2.0 I had on my GTX 970.

Lastly is price: for $611 this simply can't be beat. The options that come with this card (including stock OC and subjectively gimmicky RGB lighting) are too good to pass up. I can't recommend this card enough, it faces tough competition but I'm happy I went with this one.

summary: Quiet, perfect stock overclock, and runs coooool.

reviewText:
I bought this case with the idea that I could use it for either a Canon HF-10 (video) or a Canon S3IS (still camera). It's pretty lacking on both counts. The inner compartment has a velcro piece that allows you to customize it, but both of my cameras are so small that I just end up with a lot of wasted space. I wouldn't use the small cushion to attempt to put both cameras in the bag - that would end up making it difficult to retrieve one, and frankly, I don't trust the protection it offers - and I wouldn't trust leaving extra lenses in there unless they had some type of semi-hard case around them. The outer pockets are pretty small; sufficient for an SD or CF card, and a small battery, but plan to leave the charger behind. Same goes for a DC cord for your camera. It's an extremely tight, if not impossible, fit.

I haven't returned the case (the return shipping cost makes it not worth it), but for the most part, when I go out, I take an old camera case which is more along the lines of the Case Logic QPB-51.

reviewText:
This is probably the worst Stereo Bluetooth headset I have ever owned. I cannot even think of a good thing to say about this product.

1. Range: The range is short, my Nokia E71 is right in front of me on my table and I cannot get a continuous stream of music. Needless to say, leaving it in my front thigh pocket is out of the question.

2. Sound isolation: I am unable to have a snug fit to my ear. Thus there is no noise isolation. It works if you are in a car or a room. But if you are wearing it down the street, the surrounding noise will force you to set the music volume to almost the maximum.  After 10 minutes, I am suffering from noise fatigue.

3. Fit: It is not uncomfortable just extremely hard to get a good fit.

4. Battery life: Untested since I cannot use it for than a few minutes.

5. Sound quality: Decent, while it works.

Despite both Altec Lansing and Plantronics as the manufacturer, this product is a sore disappointment.

I bought this drive to use on two old Dell Lattitude XP laptops that have no CD/DVD drives of their own.  Each recognized the drive immediately and installed the appropriate driver. reviewText:
But I figured it out, I think, and to hook up this hub properly you will need a wall plug adapter that has a USB female port, (exactly like the one for smart phone chargers, as shown in the picture.  Can be single or double port adapter, doesn't matter).  The power adapter doesn't come with the hub for some reason, nor is it even shown in the (worthless) documentation.

But the way to hook up the hub is pretty simple once you realize it's missing the wall plug adapter.  Plug the thick USB cable (the one with USB on both ends) one end into your computer port, the other end into the hub.  Now the other cable has one round end, and one end with USB.  The cable with the small round end plugs into the hub, the other end goes into your wall adapter for the power.  Now your USB devices ought to appear.

summary: I see some people have had issues hooking this up.  But here's how you do it,

reviewText:
I first will start off by stating that I have a lot of respect for the Klipsch brand and have previously owned a set of home tower speakers and a powered subwoofer.  The subwoofer is still going strong at 17 years.  The towers, I sold a long time ago, but had great service; I blew the horn tweeters and Klipsch sent me a new pair within a week.

I had been wanting some new earbuds that were going to sound much better than the standard cheaper earbuds that most of us use.  I've had a couple of $10 Sony earbuds, a Philips, and probaby a bunch more.  If you go to Best Buy and sample all of the over-the-ear phones they have as samples: in my opinion, the Klipsch pair sound the best overall.  I can't stand Beats as they are way too bass heavy and they sucker people into buying their expensive products because of artist endorsement.  So I used some points to buy the reference S4's and ended up only actually paying about $15 for them.

Sound Quality:  I'm only going to rate these as being better than those priced say below $75-80 or less.  There might be some comparably priced Shure's or Seinheisser's that might sound just as good or better.  Since these are single driver earphones (like most are), they are only going to do so much.

Comfort/Fit:  I've never liked isolating rubber tips and this continues.  I have always simply preferred the basic cans that just sit in the ear.  Using these rubber tips never really feel like they are secure in my ears, and most of the ones that come with these are the same and fall out of my ears.  I have since ditched all the tips that came with the S4's and am using some custom DIY tips I made out of foam plugs that mold to your ear canals after you squeeze them.  This was the best idea; the plugs only cost $2 from Lowe's for 4 pair and are (1) comfortable, (2) near complete noise isolation, (3) and fit perfectly and don't fall out.

Uses:  I've used them occassionally on my DJ mixer and at work.  The real test is when I'm jogging and riding my bike.  using the OEM tips sucked ass, and they would fall out of my ears constantly...even using the sport mode of wrapping the wires around the ears.  Not a problem anymore with my DIY tips.

Overall:  If I had to do it again, I might consider similarly priced Shure's or Seinhesser's.  I've been doing a lot of research lately, and in the near future plan to buy some serious custom molded earplugs from Westone, the ES3's, that have a triple driver and triple crossover.  They are extremely pricey and not for everyone, but will serve me well for my needs when it comes to my deejaying.  If you are willing to spend a $100 on earphones, then I would consider to at least go ahead and spend a bit more and pick up some custom molded earphones with a single or double driver.  These will ultimately fit your ears perfectly, get better sound quality with a multi-driver, and get more noise isolation.  Westone, Ultimate Ears, JH Audio, Alien Ears

reviewText:
I owned both Samsung Ativ book 9 plus ultra book and kirabook i7s (4th Gen processor). Both are great ultra book laptops.
1) Design.  Samsung Ativ book 9 is slightly better.
2) Keyboard. Ativ book Keyboard is better.  I like the feel of kirabook touch pad better.
3) Speed and performance. Toshiba Kirabook i7s is faster. Tested with several apps and Toshiba kirabook is more responsive than Ativ book. Kirabook Fan is quiet all the time which is a greatly improved from previous Toshiba kirabook i7 (3rd generation)
4) Weight. Kirabook is lighter. Less than 3 lb. Samsung Ativ book 9 plus is a little bit over 3lb.
5) HDMI and USB ports. Kirabook has one HDMI port with 3 USB ports. Samsung has only one micro HDMI port with 2 USB port. Kirabook is better if you use an extended LCD monitor.
6) Screen. Samsung Ativ 9 plus is slightly better due to its higher resolution.  I like Kirabook screen color better. It looks nicer.
7) Toshiba Kirabook  comes with 2 years' Norton Antivirus service. Samsung Ativ book only comes with 6 months Norton service. Kirabook also comes with Adobe element 11.
8)Battery life. Kirabook has a 15% longer battery life than Samsung Ativbook
Overall, I like kirabook better due to its stronger performance and longer battery life and nicer screen. Although its design is not as attractive as Ativ book,  I still will give the kirabook 5 stars and Samsung 4.5 stars due to its performance difference.

reviewText:
Windows users can use it out of the box, and  it works well for storing files on the Mac manually since I have an NTFS for Mac OS X program running in the background.

However it won't work out of the box for Mac Time Machine. No problem and no kidding, once I decided this was what I wanted to do it took me all of four minutes to set up for the fix. This required a re-partition to put in a Mac OS Extended (Journaled) partition. This process took 3.9 of those 4 minutes. I went to Launchpad, then Other, then Disk Utilities, then clicked on the 480.1 GB OTG Media icon in the disk utilities app, then went through the steps of: setting up the partition, then clicking to start the partition. I'd suppose that some of the remaining 6 seconds were taken up refreshing the display on the Disk Utilities program. This thing is fast. I was expecting 20 minute but it was done before I could change songs on my iTunes. So it may have been five or two seconds in truth.

I left a small NTFS partition on the disk in case I needed to drop and drag a file using either a Windows computer or my Apple running NTFS for Mac,a program which Amazon sells but won't allow reviewers to directly link from this screen.

Using it for Time Machine it just runs without any noticeable decrease of system performance.

One caveat should be that the partitioning should be before adding any vital data files to the drive, since the Mac Disk Utility erases all the files before it partitions.

An update to this review added 4/7/15: I got a second one of these drives, a 256 mb to run on a MacBook Air. Since I knew the steps to find the disk utility and what I wanted on the format, et cetera and since I used the disk utility popup prompt to set up Time Machine it took me less than a minute to set up with new format, running Time Machine and going.

reviewText:
We are one connected family.  Five smartphones, two tablets, four laptops and a desktop.  Our internet provider, Xfinity, is not none for its' helpfulness or call center knowledge so it's important that we get routers/electronics that we can set up, independent of Xfinity.

My 16 year old son set this up in 15 minutes.  Easy to do and he didn't read the directions.  We've had this for a week.  However, I've noticed that about once a day, our internet drops suddenly.  It's usually in the early afternoon.  No storms or any interference.

My son said the antenna set up is awkward.  You have to adjust the antenna initially to make sure you get the best internet signal.  You don't have to do everytime.  Just the first.  Restart is a bit slow--it's about two minutes.  It is not small and it's taken up a shelf.  The set up requirements you to completely reboot your networks to get the router to get in sync.  This was not in the directions.

reviewText:
I've owned five different 17" laptops over the last few years and this is the best yet - in spite of a few flaws. First the flaws:

-The power chord has an odd connector that just "feels" loos or odd when connecting it. Maybe just a nerve system programming issue??

-The internal keyboard is very iffy. It just misses a lot of letters when I type them.

-The computer has a fan that sporadically decides to make a rattling noise. I just don't have the patience to send it in for repair.

-The HD video system is outdated and apparently Toshiba is doing nothing for us in spite of this. This one is almost frustrating enough to bring it down to three stars.

The positive aspects ar many, including:

-Super fast video. The dual video SLI with 512 MB of video memory runs even modern games with beautiful graphics.

-Dual hard drives. Great for running the virtual machines I run for the technical training classes I teach. If you don't know what virtual machines are, don't worry. This feature just gives you better drive performance.

-The screen is beautiful. I'm not referencing the graphics card here, but the actual screen display.

-For a laptop, the sound is the best I've had yet. I can watch a movie on it in my hotel room from across the room and the sound is clear and even has some bass to it with the subwoofer.

Now, with the flaws, you're probably wondering why I gave it four stars. Simple... the last positive: I can actually stretch this laptop to about 100 minutes on battery on a plane. I've never been able to do this with any other 17" I've owned.

Hope this helps.

reviewText:
I first wrote the review below. However, after using the antenna on a tv on the other side of the wall, I am now receiving VHF and UHF. Reception was okay, but after trying 2 or 3 different positions (lower height in the window, a bit more to the middle of the window etc.) reception is now maximized. The roku tv I use displays the signal strength for each of the channels it displays,

For most channels, this antenna picked up pure signals and had a good picture quality. I had to place the antenna at the top of a nearby window. When I moved it inside, picture quality was definitely affected. With that said, this is a UHF antenna only. From what I understand UHF is the standard for the most part, however here in Austin, the fox over the air channel is broadcast in VHF. As a result, I have to return this antenna. If there are no channels where you live broadcasting in VHF only, and you can place your antenna in a window, this should work fine. Honestly, if the local fox chanel was not broadcasting in an ancient freqency, I would be keeping this and incredibly happy

reviewText:
Like many others, the price point and many positive reviews of this wall mount drew me to look at it.  It is very inexpensive but do not equate its low price point with substandard quality...the quality of this mount is excellent!  It is a really well engineered mount, with sliding and tilting arms which attach to the TV and horizontal support brackets that fasten to the wall.  The steel it is comprised of feels very strong and I had no worries that this mount would be able to properly support the 42" Panasonic LED TV I was hanging above my fireplace.  All the mounting hardware is included (as is a 10 foot HDMI cable and a bubble level).  This is the second TV I have wall mounted, the first being over ten years ago when the process was a lot more difficult and when TV's were a lot heavier.  This was a much easier mounting process that required only minimal mechanical skill and tools, although I would still suggest having a partner.
This is also a VESA mount.  VESA is an organization that provides uniformity standards for the different brands of consumer electronics to comply with, which as far as mounts go, means that most major TV brands will have similar mounting set-ups so the process and equipment used for mounting will be standard, or 'VESA compliant'.  This mount will most likely be an excellent choice for 99% of wall mounting applications.  I give it an A+.

summary: High quality wall mount at any price!

reviewText:
This camera rivals the [$] pro cameras on the market. Add a 1 Gig IBM Microdrive and you can take 134 photos in the high res. Raw format which will easily make a perfect 13x19 print that is true photo quality. The minimum density is fantastic so skin tones are beautiful, I was shooting with a Nikon N80 and scanning the transparencies with a Canon 4000 DPI scanner. That is both expensive and time consuming. This camera is about 80% as sharp as that combo...but with a better contrast range! My average session with a model is 6-8 rolls. With 2 microdrives I can achieve that quaintly with no computer necessary! And the cost of a single drive is recouped in 3 sessions (Film and processing costs eliminated).
Cons: Horrible low light sensitivity...Slow saving in the HiRes modes and the camera controls TOTALLY lock up while the cache is written to the disk/drive (after 3 consecutive shots in HiRes ONLY). You can shoot, but not change ANYTHING manually. This problem disappears in the JPEG modes which are fine for many applications. Autofocus is slow at extreme telephoto setting and in low light. AND the shutter release button delay is intolerable when using flash or in low light.
So if you want to do a lot of action photography pick another camera. If however, you want the sharpest image for the least money then buy the Nikon Coolpix 5700. And buy several extra batteries and as large a storage device as you can afford.

reviewText: Several years ago I was able to get this product at my local Staples and only bought this product for many years.  Once they discontinued it, I purchased other brands/level of quality and it just is not worth the few dollars in savings.  I usually would loose at least 10% from most spindles from other brands or worse: accessing the data several years later and it is no longer accessible.  With this product I have yet to go back to any of my older CDs and was not able to access the data; and if I get one 'bad' CD in a spindle that is a lot.  Although I use CDs as a back-up to my back-up external drive for my photography images, as a photographer I like the fact that CDs do not hold as much -- and not have to rely 100% on a large-capacity hard drive or pen-drive.  Should my external drive fail, I have lost literally hundreds of images in one swipe; by backing up 100 or so images in increments I feel more confident -- and I would only trust that confidence to the Maxell Pro Gold Series.

reviewText:
I bought my Belkin Wireless G Desktop Network Card at Wal-Mart for $35.00 about three months ago. What a mistake! The card keeps shutting off no matter what I do. The only way that I can get it to work (for awhile) is to literally "play around" with the buttons on the splash screen until it decides to come on again. It will stay on for awhile then shut down again. Ok, so let me call the Belkin phone number (on the box) and find out what to do. Well the phone service is nothing but a bunch of meaningless taped messages which can't solve anything of substance. Pure frustration! There is NO real live PERSON to help you! Ok, So now let's try their e-mail troubleshooting service. Had the tab for about a month now and am loving it. It's responsive with great graphics. There are a few little nit-picks, but none worthy of much attention, like the power button (getting better but still fumble with it). Matsunichi has a great reputation for personal electronics and the Le Pan tablet is no exception - sturdy and built really well despite being a bit heavy. I'd rather have a little heft, though, than a machine that falls apart.

I also purchased a Verbatim folding keyboard and a folding stand, so I carry this home instead of my laptop many nights. Want to read outside? Wear a dark shirt or get a matte screen protector, but it's going to be reflective due to its shiny face. I can cope, though.

I wanted to get a couple of extra cables and got fast response from their support folks in California. That was a very nice thing when dealing with a brand I had never heard of. If they keep up the level of service that I got, they'll capture a large share of the market quickly.

Would I buy it again? Absolutely. Do my friends like it? Yes, all of them (a bit of jealousy, too). Any buyer's remorse? Nope. Should you get one? That's up to you, but I'm quite happy with mine. Just hoping for an upgrade to Honeycomb soon.

reviewText:
There are so, so many of these dash cams out there, and they're becoming more popular in the US, so I figured I should get ahead of the game and try one out in my car.

The device comes well-boxed with a car charger (cigarette lighter with a long, long cable (about 4 feet) to micro USB), a regular micro USB cable for your computer, a suction cup, and that's about it. It's a very through-the-motions packaging experience. Nothing fancy, and the camera itself is a little plastic-y. The buttons on the camera have a very satisfying click to them, and my sample's regular LCD screen looked just fine (if not HD), with no stuck/dead pixels or other screen anomalies.

Setup was a little trickier than I'd have liked, - it's not a touch screen, and the button layout is not instinctively intuitive. Once you have it set up (date/time etc), it all becomes a lot simpler as you'll likely just be hitting the record button.

Getting a micro SD card into the unit took a bit of finagling. I ended up using a credit card to push it in all the way as I don't really have any nails to speak of. In a positive sense, at least it won't be popping out by mistake!

Image quality is actually quite decent. There's a slight fish-bowl look to things, a result of the extremely wide lens in there to capture everything very close in front of you (in the event of a collision, for example). Cars come out pretty well defined, and you'd have no trouble reading license plates when the car in front is reasonably close to you. This is important, so I'm glad it works.

Curiously, while you can zoom in and out, you cannot do this while the camera is recording. However, to be fair, it's just a digital zoom (there's no physical lens movement that I can tell), so you don't gain any extra detail by zooming in anyway. If you have some basic editing tools at home, you can always zoom in as necessary, after the fact.

The GSHOCK option in the camera menu I found quite interesting. You can set it to low, medium, or high sensitivity, and the camera will record if it detects any sudden shock to the device. This could be particularly handy if someone crashes into you when you're parked, although if they ram the back of your car, you might well be wishing you had another camera in the back window! At the highest sensitivity (my recommendation), it did a pretty decent job when I tapped the camera mount itself - starting recording immediately, though I'll wait till someone reverses into my car to test that feature out extensively!

There are a few software quirks (e.g. to turn the device off you have to hold down the power button for a second or two... and then let go. If you don't let go, it never actually turns off! Weird), and the interface definitely takes a little getting used to, but, you know.., the Esky 2.4" Full HD car camera does a pretty decent job - doing basically what it sets out to do, and it works.

Overall, 4 out of 5. Certainly recommended for those in need of a dash-cam fix!

*Sample provided for objective review*

reviewText:
This is one of those you get what you pay for type products.

First off, if you expecting an OEM battery you can spend 6x what this one costs to get those standards. I call these my back up batteries that I use first while on a shoot or out in the field.

I have 2 Canon OEM batteries which can be recharged for years, have no problem communicating, and are my reliable sources of power. Along with those 2 OEM Batteries I have 4 of these inexpensive batteries that do the job when my shooting is a little more flexible. They probably hold about 80% of the charge an OEM battery has and after a 12-18 months I expect my camera may stops communicating all together or it will no longer hold a charge. That's the nature of the game.

However, if you go into this purchase knowing that then you shouldn't be surprised if one dies on you. When you're out in the field and you need power I recommend using your OEM battery last and using these batteries first. They will more than likely give you all the charge you need for your shoot however you have the added insurance of an OEM workhorse sitting in your bag ready to go if you run out of juice. With one exception, don't rely on these batteries during a "no second chance shoot". Meaning I wouldn't have these batteries in my camera during the wedding ceremony or the start of a race, however if you are doing staged shots or won't be affected when the battery runs out of juice and you have to switch batteries then you will be fine.

Again for the price they are offering these at you can have 5-6x the power in your bag, however they do not replace the reliability of an OEM battery, so don't assume they do.

I already have one of these for my main Nikon D7000 ( I have two D7000's). These grips hold up allot better then the aftermarket junk that sells for $40. Anyways the grip arrived 4 days early! That's really good if you ask me. The box arrived in perfect condition. The grip itself was also flawless.

The main reason why I bought this grip is because I like to shoot with primes. So I usually just carry two bodies around with me. I wasn't going to buy a second grip for my other D7000 because these grips used to sell for $250+ a few years ago. But when I saw that Adorama was selling these for $169 I said screw it and bought myself an early Christmas present.

If you ask me I think Nikon should be selling all of their grips for $169. They ask  $350 for their newer grips which is ridiculous if you ask me.

Overall I'm very happy with this purchase. I got a brand new OEM grip for a really good deal. I have no intention of up grading anytime soon which means I'll get my money's worth out of this grip.

reviewText:
I bought this camera for my family's special Disney World vacation and took about 1,300 pictures with it over an eight days period and was utterly stunned by the results.  It was really easy to use, performance was lightning quick and the zoom lens on digital SLR feels so natural.  I can take pictures pretty much as fast as I can press the shutter which is really great.  I shot mostly in Auto or Potrait mode and the picture quality especially of potraits were breath-taking.  People's skin and complexion were exceptionally sharp, soft and natural looking not washed out like my other point-and-shoot camera.  And I absolutely love the wide angle composition that I was able to get from my 18-70mm lens so I get the people and the landscape at the same time.

It's a significant premium over my Canon Powershot S3 point-and-shoot camera but well worth it.  I am starting to learn to use it's more advance feature for creative photography and loving it even more.

reviewText:
I just used this to mount my 51 inch Sharp Aquos and it worked out great. The product was sturdy and installation was straight forward (once you find the center of the studs and get the measurements down). It does take two people to install properly. Ignore the included levels. They are rubbish. Use a real one that is at least a foot long to make sure the part that swings out is level (not the base that attaches to the wall).
I did look in local big box stores, but they wanted about $100 more than this for a basic mount. Finding an articulated mount with this quality at this price was a real find.

reviewText: I was about to pull the trigger on the Logitech Z906 speakers but they are still pricey. So I bought this device to work with a set of Logitech 5300 5.1 speakers that I have had since around 2006. Anyways I wanted the speakers to play through a TV, Xbox One, PS4, and my HTPC computer. This thing only had 2 optical ports but I needed 4. I then bought the Panlong Digital Optical Audio Switch Splitter 4 In 2 with remote. Panlong Digital Optical Audio Switch Splitter 4 In 2 Out Toslink Matrix Switcher Selector 4x2 with Remote Control. I connected the Panlong 5.1 decoder to the speakers (3) 3.5mm and one optical cable to the Panlong digital optical audio switch splitter. Then I connected the 4 devices to the 4 optical ports on the Panlong digital optical audio switch splitter. I now have a use for my 5300 speakers again with a remote to switch inputs. I am now getting 5.1 sound from all sources ( the optical out on most TV's only provide Dolby for the built in tuner). A diagram is included. Hope this helps someone who has the 5300 or the (3) 3.5mm connector.

reviewText: I have used other powerline adapters (primarily Netgear). The only advantage the PLA-407 has is the noise-filtering front outlet but this is outweighed by the awful software & difficult encryption setup. THE GOOD: + Noise filtering front outlet allows you to plug in extension cords or other devices without affecting the PLA network speed due to noisy devices. Note that the PLA-407 is a 200Mbps powerline device (there are faster 500Mbps devices but these are typically more expensive) + Adapter supports manually-set priority levels PER ADAPTER. You can designate an adapter to have higher priority than another one set to "Normal" for example. Note this is not "true" Quality of Service based on analysis of transmitted data etc but a simple priority scheme to allow certain adapters to have better/worse priority than others. THE BAD: The Zyxel PLA config utility v4.1.2 software is truly awful: - The configuration screen is not intuitive or friendly. The config utility seems like a prototype and not a production/end-user tool. - The utility does not show the existing network name (NMK) so you cannot tell if all adapters are setup correctly with the same name. (What Zyxel calls the network name other manufacturers refer to as the powerline password). This may be for security reasons, so you better keep track of your network name otherwise if you want to add a device later and don't remember the name you'll have to reconfig the name on all PLA devices. - Related to the above point, since you CANNOT tell what the network name is you can't tell whether the PLA is using the default (i.e. unsecure) name or a custom name. This means you will have to keep notes, especially if setting up multiple adapters. - The firmware update function is handled by a separate utility which must be downloaded. The firmware utility says "Your device is doing with new firmware" when updating (no, that's not my typo). - The default "green power-down" feature can confuse you when using the PC config utility if you don't realise that a PLA adapter that does not have an ethernet connection to a powered-up device will go to "sleep" after 60 seconds and will NOT show up or respond in the PC config utility. The default timeout should be longer than 60 seconds to accommodate setup. (As an aside there seems to be no way to extend or disable the low power mode from the PC config utility). I'm all for saving power but this makes simultaneous configuration difficult (i.e. multiple adapters at the same time) as they will all need to be connected to a POWERED-UP device with an ethernet port) to prevent them from going to sleep! - At 1st glance there appears to be no way to figure out what firmware version each PLA is using from the config utility. Hidden in the "about" icon (next to the question mark) it shows the utility version and "firmware version" but I have no idea which adapter has this firmware (i.e. it is showing a firmware version but not indicating which adapter has this version - remember the utility can show multiple adapters) - The firmware utility doesn't show the existing version before upgrading. - The encryption method using the button procedure indicated in the user guide PDF did not work for me - as another reviewer noted the LEDs don't flash as the manual indicates. I believe the manual is incorrect. OVERALL I don't recommend this PLA adapter if you care about configuring/implementing security because of the PC config software - shame on you Zyxel for having the worst software that I've ever seen on a powerline adapter (Zyxel: get the guys who did the excellent interface on the NSA320 NAS to fix your PLA software!) If you don't care about security and plug it in "out of the box" (with no security) then this may work for you. But there are cheaper PLA solutions (especially if you don't need the front noise-filtering outlet) such as the TP-Link Powerline Adapter (TL-PA211 STARTER KIT). I hope you have found this helpful!

reviewText:
This active stylus works really well with Nokia Lumia 2520. There's the wavy line problem in some apps. This problem is with the app because  the pen works perfectly in the Bamboo Apps. In all apps palm rejection works but only if the pen touches the screen first. This may be adjustable in settings but I have only had the pen for a few hours so can't be certain. If not Targus has a cheap cleaning pad you can wear on your hand while you write. The plus to that solution is that it both cleans and keeps your screen clean while you write. I also plan to get MetiMoji Note Pro which has a palm rejection pane. An option some users may want to consider. Also the pen stays connected through Bluetooth well but if you accidentally hit the button on the side you will have to go into Bluetooth options click forget device and then pair the device again. Also within Bamboo Paper from the Windows Store you get all the available tools packs free. The app is also free. I am not sure if pressure sensitivity works I have not checked the Settings because typically I prefer it not to. Offset from the pen tip is barely noticeable and only when you hold the pen at an extreme angle. Works marvelously with handwriting recognition in the handwriting board that is an alternative to the on screen keyboard.  I gave four stars instead of five bc I think it needs a little tweaking and should not just be marketed for iPad especially since apparently it works better with other devices. Get this pen you will be glad you did! Also there are other drawing apps I have not tried that have active stylus support that I plan on trying.

Update:
Pressure sensitivity seems to work in Sketchable fairly well as well as in Bamboo Paper. Palm rejection works as long as the pen touches first for both of these apps. The more I use the pen in other apps the more the wavy line issue seems to go away. I also am probably adapting to the pen but I think it is adapting also. Diagonals were the worst like an X but they are clearing up. Palm rejection seems to be improving as well. One problem is that once the pen gets low on power it's less reliable like when writing the lower case e some how it comes out a c and has to be erased and rewritten.
Someone asked about if this pen works well for drawing I bought the Sketchable app pack and tried it out, when I tried to answer their question thoroughly something went wrong and I couldn't so I am posting here in the update section. The pen seems to work well enough for drawing. A tip though is that if you often lean your drawing utensils at extreme angles like I do pay attention to the cursor and go by it for drawing BC there will often be an offset but even it seems to improve with use.

reviewText:
After reading the "easy instructions" that seemed like 1 - 2 - 3... it didn't work for me after 30 minutes of trying. I'm pretty good at setting things up.... I set up my Wireless Access Point and a Slingbox for example. Well, I knew something was up (prolly with the router settings) so I called Linksys Tech Support and it got routed to The Philippines. The lady asked me if I wanted to pay $9.99 and she would go into my computer and set it up herself using WebEx. I said, "Sure - why not??" I was already intrigued by this... even though I didn't think I should have to pay, but it's guaranteed or else you will not be charged.

After I paid, I spent about an hour with her and was able to see everything she was doing, which was manually. She also installed my camera software and set that up as well.  Of course, I had to be her assistant and plug the camera in and out and such. She did a pretty good job and I was able to ask her questions in regards to setting it up on the web. I would never have figured any of that out in that little time.

I'm happy with the purchase for what I use it for (The Kitty Poo Cam!). It's placed directly above my cat box so when I go out of town and if it needs help when it malfunctions, I'm able to call my neighbor to come help!

The quality isn't so great, but it's still doable. Plus, before, I had a $30 Logitech Webcam with an additional $15 USB extender and a crazy wire going through my condo that would not be reliable as well, so paying the extra $55 is well worth it!

Check it out @ kittycampoo dot com for the quality.

reviewText:
I've had this for 2 years now and love it! At the time, I wanted a camcorder so I can record my kids and put them on youtube to share with family far away. Before this I've been using my Canon Powershot Camera but the video quality is horrible and the file is too big. I also was eyeing the Flip Video but it was too expensive so I chose this one.

I love the video quality! In lighted condition, the quality is excellent. I can record my children's milestones and shenanigans and share it with family through youtube. In low light the picture is grainy but that's the case whatever camcorder you use anyway. I have a Canon DV camcorder and it takes grainy videos in low light as well.

Ease of use is excellent. I can shoot a video and go to my computer right away and upload it to youtube. The battery life is great!  I haven't tested the waterproof claim and I don't plan on it. I don't need to shoot underwater. :)

The zoom on the video camera is better than my Canon POwershot. I used this on the beach and was able to shoot my husband body surfing from far away. This is good for school performances which I've already had. My 3 year old twins had a school spring presentation and caught it nicely from from the back row (I think I was more than 50 feet away from the stage).

The picture quality is good outdoors. But other than that, I don't like it and don't use it for this purpose. The only time I use it is if I was video taping and thought what was happening would be great in picture. I go ahead and do that while filming. That's a nice feature.

The camera uses a SDHC card. If your laptop or computer uses the old SD cards (not HC), you'll need an adapter.

reviewText:
I compared performance and test images taken with the Sigma 10-20 f/3.5 against my Nikon 16-85 VRII, which I consider to be my sharpest lens.  The photos were taken with a Nikon D5000, tripod mounted, no digital sharpening, of fixed targets on my living room wall at about six feet.  The targets consisted of newspaper at the corners and a large US map in the center, with a variety of detail and some color. Illumination was provided by house lamps and a photo flood light. The photos were compared side by side at 200% enlargement.

The Sigma 10-20 was not as sharp as the Nikon 16-85 in the very center of the image at comparable focal lengths (16mm  and 20mm) and apertures, although was very close by f/5 and nearly the same at f/8.  At the edges of the image however, the Sigma 10-20 was as sharp or sharper and had better contrast at all f-stops tested (3.5-8).  I have no lens to compare the Sigma 10-20 to at shorter focal lengths but Imaging Resource tests indicate good to very good sharpness, similar to the older Sigma 10-20.

Focus speed with the Sigma 10-20 is very fast and quiet, similar to the Nikon 16-85. There is some variation in auto focus reproducibility but seems to be within a reasonable margin of error and will likely not be noticable in most photographs. The zoom action of the Sigma is smoother than the Nikon.  The lens is somewhat larger and heavier than the Nikon.

Chromatic aberration/color fringing has been reported as being an issue with many wide angle lenses, including this lens. I will comment on this after shooting some high contrast scenes outdoors if I feel it is significant.

This is my second copy of the lens.  The first copy appeared to have a slight back focus problem at 10mm at short focal distances as indicated by variations in auto focus performance vs manual focus to achieve optimal sharpness. Optically, the first copy appeared as sharp as this one and likely would have been acceptable to most users.

First edit 9-30-09: Outdoor shots posted in the gallery. The lens performed well in the field yielding good color and contrast. Flaring is visible as the lens is tilted towards the sun. I used my baseball cap to shade the lens and would also recommend the lens hood in most situations.  At 10mm, sharpness is acceptable at f3.5 in the center and quite soft at the edges. Sharpness at the edges seems fairly good by f4.5. Color fringing is quite evident in high contrast areas near the edges of the image however it was not so bright as to apppear in uncorrected 8x10 prints. Also it was quite easy to reduce the fringing to a non-issue with CA correction using Adobe CS4. Auto focus was accurate. Overall I'm quite pleased with this lens and I'd say it outperforms my expectations for sharpness and vignetting but I wish the CA was better controlled. I will keep this lens, however the older version (f4-5.6) is reported to be as good or perhaps better in some respects so I'd recommend the f3.5 lens only if the constant aperature is of interest to you.

reviewText:
We bought this to replace a 7 year old Netgear router that needed to be rebooted daily and was slow, and for some reason never connected well with Apple products.

All issues were solved with this new N900 Router, even though setup FOR ME was tough because we have an old Vonage router that I have to keep and the instructions were terrible regarding setup with other routers (doesn't really say anything about it, they just assume it's your only router).

So, I went to advanced settings, device mode and chose "Extender Mode" which just makes it a wireless access point.  And I went the Advanced LAN settings and turned OFF DHCP, which is the service to assign IP addresses, which the Vonage router already does, and since it's first in line after the cable modem, it's best to let it do that.  Also, in "Extender Mode" DO NOT connect this to your other router in the N900 yellow internet port!  Use one of the regular ethernet ports!  They don't tell you this but you will have nothing but problems if you do.  I also had to change the N900's IP address to 192.168.1.101 instead of the default, which is already my Vonage router's address in my LAN. (in the HOST LAN settings screen, LAN IP address "address of the router on the network")

Now all of our phones (Windows 8, Apple, Android), our laptops, Nooks, DVD players etc. all connect fine and stay connected, and IT IS FAST!  My Win8 phone was SLOOWWW, and now it's blazin' on web and downloads!

I saw a lot of reviewers from last year had issues, they must have updated the firmware.

reviewText:
I've had several Logitech mice through the years since the early nineties when I got my first computer.  I've had two other cordless mice.  I was in love with the last one but, sadly, I fell prey to the "new machine" illness currently sweeping the land, i.e., I got a machine preloaded with #@&*#@ Windows Vista.  Nothing worked on the new machine that I'd been so comfy with on the old machine, not even my beloved mouse.

(They don't tell you, those tricksey salespeople, that when you buy Vista, you'll have to buy "updated" versions of all your current programs, too, programs like Paint Shop, all your games [like Scrabble, Boggle and Bejeweled] and your virus protection programs.  And WOW does that upgrading move quickly into some serious dollars!)

So I had to get another mouse, one that was Vista-compatible.

This mouse is as good as any I've used from this company and better than a couple.  The ergonomics is superb.  It fits smoothly into my hand and I don't have to reach for anything; it's all there at the slightest touch of fingertips or my thumb.  I love the very, very dark blue color--plain black or black/silver was getting a tad boring and I didn't even know it.  Another good thing is that once you begin to use to use the mouse for the first time, it guides you to a site wherein you can easily, painlessly, download the software for the mouse, right there at the site.  No more tiny strings of numbers to read off boxes that have already gone into the recycling bin.  I LOVE that!

This is a wonderful mouse.  It's got a lot of power and oomph for a small price.  You want a really good, basic cordless mouse?  This is the one for you, in my opinion.  (-:

reviewText:
Edit: Two weeks after posting this review, the battery life precipitously dropped to 40 minutes. Then, a week later to 30 minutes. Now the unit won't even charge enough to pair. So it worked fine but not for long. I'm not changing the star rating because I suspect I got a defective unit as a sample.

This is a well functioning Bluetooth headphone set. The phones come in a nice case making them travel well. The wire holding the two earpieces forms a spring which folds the phones back into position to fit into the case and also create a tension holding them to you allowing for even vigorous movement without danger of the phones falling off.

The earpieces are finished in shiny black which is all the rage today in audio devices. The multifunction switch is located in the inside of the kidney shaped right earpiece making it easy to find. However the multicolor LED which you need to consult to determine the state of the multifunction button or charging status is nearby and not easy to see. My huge hands weren't able to control the gain control while the phones were in place. Someone with smaller delicate hands would, no doubt, have better luck.

The phones pair easily. The sound is as expected or on par with inexpensive wired headphones. It's more than good enough for speech and decent for music. The range is quite good. After pairing, I left the source machine (an iPhone) in the sunroom and wandered all over the yard even out of sight of the sunroom (around a corner) never losing the signal. The headphones stayed in place even during gardening which includes a lot of movement and bending.

The sample provided here included the case, a charging cord (USB to micro USB) and two optional set of ear seals (larger and smaller than standard). If the manufacturer could solve the problem of too small controls which, due to the small size of the unit will be challenge, these phones would be perfect. As they are, they work very well looking good as they do.
